bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, January 9, 1920

div1.p: Carter informs Russell about the progress that she and Frost made over the Christmas holiday and about the maps and bibliographical references for the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever that she is currently working on.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, January 9, 1920
div1.opener:
Book,
Misel.
Report. Russell
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
January 9, 1930.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
1: As Dr. Frost may have told you, he and I got in some
satisfactory work together during the Xmas holidays. Indeed, he said,
on January 2nd., that if he could only get seven more consecutive days,
he believed that he could complete the final editing. He added, how-
ever, that he saw no chance of this and would have to, from that time
on, utilize any spare time as it arose, even to hours and half hour.s.
These fragments will, of course, eventually mount up to the necessary
total, but it is hard to be “so near...and yet so far!”...from a defi-
nite prognosis as to the time of the completion of this work. Equally
hard on Dr. Frost, since we know how anxious he is for the book to go
to press.

I came back to Washington on December 27th. for a lot of refer-
ence books and other material for Dr. Frost, returning with them to
Baltimore on December 29th., after a strenuous session at this end with
Miss Brown. Dr. Frost and I worked until about 11.30 the night of my
return to Baltimore, which gave us a good start for the next day.

ii. I also brought back with me to Washington, a list, given me by Dr.
Frost concerning certain references about which he considers further data
advisable. This list I have divided with Miss Brown and we are both
actively engaged on it.

iii: I am glad to state that Dr. Frost expected to get Mrs. Smiley
started on the typing of the final copy of the Sections he has already
edited just as soon as she could do so. Indeed, I expect that she has
begun by now. We couldn't have a better person handle this work. Also,
her starting now will, of course, greatly lessen the delay in getting
getting
-2-
our final copy ready for the printer.

iv: I had my Library of Congress priveleges renewed last
December for as much of 1930 as may be necessary..i. e. have been allowed
to keep my desk and large accumulation of reference books: also still
have access to the stacks and can take home books bearing on Father's
MS. But for this, it would have been extremely difficult to cooperate
with Dr. Frost in our work during the holdidays or for Miss Brown and
myself to continue further research for him.

v: I hope soon to be able to resume what is left of my work on
the maps..i. e. (a) write out instructions re the inking in of No. i
and No. ii: (b) finish checking historical data for our xvi th. Century
shore-line map. This, I had intended doing during the holidays, but was
more than glad to be able to work with Dr. Frost instead, as the illus-
trative material will only be needed after the MS is ready for the
printer. Any additional data required by Dr. Frost in the final editing
must, of course, take precedence over everything else and, as I have al-
ready stated, Miss Brown and myself have been working early and late,
since my return, both at the Library of Congress and at my apartment try-
ing to clear things up. Some very good luck: other things, on which we
have worked long and hard, still in “status quo.” These things, of course,
have all been worked over previously, and belong in the list of “dimin-
ishing returns,” of which Dr. Frost spoke so feelingly in the fall of
1928!

With very best wishes, and hoping that the book--as such!--may
be among the good things the New Year has to give us!
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
